response: The Alaska Department of Snow (ADS) coordinates snow removal services across the state to ensure safe and efficient travel. ADS works with local municipalities and regional offices to schedule and prioritize plowing routes, focusing first on high-traffic roads, emergency routes, and schools. If you need to report an unplowed road, you should contact your local ADS regional office, which maintains a hotline for snow-related service requests.

The Alaska Department of Snow (ADS) coordinates snow removal services across the state to ensure safe, efficient travel and infrastructure continuity. ADS works with local municipalities and regional offices to schedule and prioritize plowing routes, focusing first on high-traffic roads, emergency routes, and schools. If you need to report an unplowed road, you should contact your local ADS regional office, as each region maintains a hotline for snow-related service requests.

You can check current road conditions statewide by using the ADS “SnowLine” app or by visiting the official ADS website’s road conditions dashboard. The dashboard is updated hourly with closures and warnings. The ADS “SnowLine” app also offers real-time plow tracking and road conditions.

While the Alaska Department of Snow (ADS) provides data on snow conditions, final school closure decisions are made by local school districts. ADS coordinates closely with these districts to keep them informed.

ADS uses a centralized coordination system shared with local governments, school districts, and emergency services to streamline announcements and responses, which would include communications related to emergencies.
To report an unplowed road, you should contact your local ADS regional office. Each region maintains a hotline specifically for snow-related service requests and emergencies.
